div.p: From Clara Wehl to Henrietta Sinclair
RB MSS M197, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

MS envelope (edged in black) front: 'Mrs D. Sinclair jun Renmark'. Annotations on back: 'Baron Von Muellers death ', and 'written by his sister Clara Wehl to her daughter Henrietta "Ettie"'. Millicent
SA.

To morrow I am returning to Ehren,
'Ehrenbreitstein', the Wehl family home at Millicent. so will answer your letter which I received a little while ago. I had also one from Bertha, Tillie, George
Clara Wehl's children Bertha Harris, Matilde Overheu and George Wehl. & others. Have about 2 doz to answer, but leave them till I am home again & can gather my thoughts, am still half dazed & cannot realize it all; and I am so sorry dear Ettie, to give you another sad news; by to nights post we received a letter from the Minister at Penola
SA. to let us know that pour Bessie
Henrietta Sinclair's school friend, Bessie Barrow. passed away peacefully on Monday morning at 5 o clock & will be burried at Mt. Gambier to morrow. I am so dreadfully sorry for poor Mab. Meta
Clara Wehl's youngest child Meta (m. Stenhouse). had a letter from her a few days ago saying Bessie had a bad turn again & was just then lying in the verandah. She has been very weak for some time, & was ordered by the Dr. to lie out in the Sun as much as possible. When she was at Ehren last I did not think she would live much longer; but she was bright as ever. I am sure it is a happy release for her, but little Mab is to be pittied; & her father thought so much of her. Pour girl sent me a message of condolence by male & would have liked to write herself but did not feel equal to it.

I am sorry we could not let you know about Uncle sooner, we were all so shocked it came upon us so suddenly, I really did not know what I ought to be doing. fortunately Will
Clara Wehl's son William. was here & could go to give him the last honors. The funeral was delayed a day to give him time to come, it took place Tuesday afternoon. When Will arrived at Uncles Cottage he was met at the gate by the head assistant & led into Uncles room; he says he will never forget the sight; the coffin was coverd with the most beautifull wreaths, also the bed & heaps of them in adjoining room. After he had changed his [...] etc the procession started. In the first carriage Willie & Uncles dearest freinds & Executors Rev. Potter, Doctor Büttner & brother
Alexander Büttner and his brother Hermann. & Dr Rudall. a long line of carriages followed & those on foot walked on both sides, thousands followed, Will was told by several, such a sight had never been seen in Melbourne before. The Turn Verein
Turn Verein written in German script.
in light clothes with banners their band playing the dead march from Saul, at the grave the Liedertafel
Liedertafel written in German script.
sang 2 beautifull hyms. The grave was lined with green creepers & Roses, a thick layer of flowers at the bottom & all around so that no earth was to be seen & afterwards the wreath's coverd it & roap railling round it was hung with wreath. Will said it was all beautifull & he could see real sympathy in everybody's face even the little street urchins look sad. Dear Uncle was so good & kind to everyone.

Those Gentlemen I mentioned, Will says were like brothers to Uncle & some of them have undertaken to look after his papers & works & see that all will be caried out as he wished; what he was possesd of will be sold, to pay expenses for for the finishing & publishing of the last parts of his works. Dear Uncle was very anxious about that.
M in his will (in this edition as 84-06-17) had indicated several items that he wanted published; none of them were. Clara Wehl and her family later became thoroughly disillusioned with the way the executors were handling M's affairs; see C. Wehl to C. Doughty, 12 March 1901 (in this edition as M1901-03-12). Uncle took a bad turn on friday afternoon & passed away peacefully about 2 a.m. Saturday morn. Rev. Potter said he had never seen him look so peacefull & happy in life.
